name: sturnus-vulgaris
definition: The common starling is a medium-sized, noisy passerine bird in the starling family, Sturnidae.
description:
Common starling is a noisy bird, especially when gather for rest or sleep, or other gregarious situations, with an unmusical but varied song.

The common starling plumage is iridescent black, glossed purple or green, and spangled with white, especially in winter.

The underparts of adult male are less spotted than those of adult females at a given time of year.

The throat feathers of males are long and loose and are used in display while those of females are smaller and more pointed.

The bill is narrow and conical with a sharp tip; in the winter it is brownish-black but in summer, females have lemon yellow beaks while males have yellow bills with blue-grey bases.

The common starling is 19 to 23 centimeters long, with a wingspan of 31 to 44 centimeters and a weight of 58 to 101 grams.

Among standard measurements, the wing chord is 11.8 to 13.8 centimeters, the tail is 5.8 to 6.8 centimeters, and the tarsus is 2.7 to 3.2 centimeters.

Common starlings prefer urban or suburban areas where artificial structures and trees provide adequate nesting and roosting sites.

Reedbeds are also favoured for roosting and the birds commonly feed in grassy areas such as farmland, grazing pastures, playing fields, golf courses and airfields where short grass makes foraging easy.

The common starling is largely insectivorous and feeds on both pest and other arthropods.

The food range includes spiders, crane flies, moths, mayflies, dragonflies, damsel flies, grasshoppers, earwigs, lacewings, caddisflies, flies, beetles, sawflies, bees, wasps and ants.

Prey are consumed in both adult and larvae stages of development, and common starlings will also feed on earthworms, snails, small amphibians and lizards.

While the consumption of invertebrates is necessary for successful breeding, common starlings can also eat grains, seeds, fruits, nectar and food waste if the opportunity arises.

Breeding takes place during the spring and summer. The female lays eggs on a daily basis over a period of several days.

There are normally four or five eggs that are ovoid in shape and pale blue .

Incubation lasts thirteen days, although the last egg laid may take 24 hours longer than the first to hatch.

Both parents share the responsibility of brooding the eggs, but the female spends more time incubating them than does the male, and is the only parent to do so at night when the male returns to the communal roost.

The young are born blind and naked.

They develop light fluffy down within seven days of hatching and can see within nine days.

A majority of starling predators are avian.

The typical response of starling groups is to take flight, with a common sight being undulating flocks of starling flying high in quick and agile patterns.

Their abilities in flight are seldom matched by birds of prey.

Adult common starlings are hunted by hawks such as the northern goshawk and Eurasian sparrowhawk, and falcons including the peregrine falcon, Eurasian hobby and common kestrel.

Slower raptors like black and red kites, eastern imperial eagle, common buzzard and Australasian harrier tend to take the more easily caught fledglings or juveniles.

facts.name: Young birds can fly at 18 days
facts.value: Young birds can fly at the age of 18 to 21 days, but they are not ready for the independent life at least one or two weeks.

facts.name: European starling is an omnivore
facts.value: European starling is an omnivore (it eats plants and meat). Its diet is based on the millipedes, spiders, snails and worms during the winter. Berries, seed, grains and fruit are major source of food during the summer.

facts.name: Can survive more than 15 years
facts.value: European starling can survive more than 15 years in the wild. There is a documented record of 22 years and 11 months.

facts.name: Female lays 5 to 7 bluish eggs
facts.value: Female lays 5 to 7 bluish eggs in the second half of April. Both parents take part in the incubation of eggs (that lasts 15 days) and provide food for their chicks.

facts.name: Nest made by both male and female
facts.value: Both male and female participate in the construction of the nest. They use leaves, wool, feathers, moss and twigs to fill the interior of the cavity.

facts.name: Help eliminating pest from crops
facts.value: European starling eliminates pest from the crops, but it also inflicts serious damage on the commercially important types of fruit.

facts.name: Gather in large numbers before dusk
facts.value: Large numbers of European starlings often congregate before the dusk near  the roosting areas to sing, preen their plumage and to rest in the group.

facts.name: Gregarious birds that live in large flocks
facts.value: European starlings are gregarious birds that live in large flocks especially on the wintering grounds. Group of European starlings is known as "constellation", "filth" or "scourge" of starlings.

facts.name: Produces various unmusical songs
facts.value: European starling produces various unmusical songs that are composed of whistles, chuckles and rattling sounds. It can mimic songs of other birds and sound of human speech.

facts.name: Uses its beak to find food hidden in the soil
facts.value: European starling uses its beak to find food hidden in the soil.

facts.name: European starling has pointed bill
facts.value: European starling has pointed bill, short wings and tail and pinkish-red legs.

facts.name: Covered with black plumage
facts.value: European starling is covered with black plumage with purple and green sheen. Black feathers with white tips can be seen during the autumn, creating mottled appearance. By the end of the winter, tips of the feathers become worn out and European starlings are once again completely black. Hatchlings are covered with grey-brown plumage. Young birds attain adult coloration quickly, but their head remains grey until they reach adulthood.

facts.name: Can reach 23 centimeters length
facts.value: European starling can reach 19 to 23 centimeters in length and 58 to 101 grams of weight.

facts.name: Color of the bill depends on the season
facts.value: Color of the bill depends on the season. European starling has yellow bill during the spring and black bill during the winter.

facts.name: Produce two broods per season
facts.value: European starlings produce two broods per season. They compete with native, cavity-nesting birds for the holes in the tree or for the abandoned nests of woodpeckers.

related.definition: The common nightingale is a small passerine bird best known for its powerful and beautiful song.
A widespread Eurasian finch having green and yellow plumage.
The European goldfinch is a small passerine bird in the finch family that is native to Europe, North Africa and western Asia.
The chipping sparrow  is a species of American sparrow, a passerine bird in the family Passerellidae.
